Items.Description:
When big tech companies say they love open formats and protocols, that means they're launching something new and they're just saying that so you relax about their intentions, which haven't actually changed at all.

That's why I say if they really want to prove their love for the open web, if they aren't just trying to lull us to sleep while they steal yet another market from the open web, they should do something that helps the web more than it helps them.

I know how The Mind of Facebook works. There are people at the company who believe in the open web (or at least there were at one time) and some of them have the ability to launch projects to be part of the open web, but by the time the project has to get approval from

one of the top execs, it dies -- because Zuck et al have hearts of stone, and think they can have anything that isn't nailed down, and thinks anyone who believes in being fair to users and competitors is a chump -- a Mother Teresa type, someone to laugh at not work with.

There are very few people in the world as greedy and mean as Zuckerberg. Never underestimate how cold his heart is. And never believe he will do anything that benefits anyone but him.

I'm going through my Alice Cooper phase. Again. When I was a teen I loved the band. I always felt kind of ashamed of it. I used to go to their concerts to see what he'd do this time.

I must have seen him guillotined a dozen times. He knew what fascinated teenage boys. Anyway the song rolling around in my head today is the classic Dead Babies. It's a really awful song, I guess that's why I like it so much. 💥

Cream was a British rock supergroup formed in 1966, consisting of guitarist Eric Clapton, bassist Jack Bruce, and drummer Ginger Baker. Their fusion of blues, rock, and psychedelic influences captivated audiences worldwide. Cream's meteoric rise was fueled by their electrifying live performances and groundbreaking studio albums.

They released four studio albums in their brief existence, including "Fresh Cream" (1966) and "Disraeli Gears" (1967), which showcased their virtuosity and innovative songwriting. Hits like "Sunshine of Your Love" and "White Room" became iconic rock anthems.

However, the band's intense personalities and clashing egos led to tension and ultimately their dissolution in 1968. Despite their short tenure, Cream left an indelible mark on the music world, inspiring countless musicians with their innovative approach.

Each member went on to have successful solo careers, solidifying their status as legendary figures in rock history. Cream's music continues to resonate with fans, serving as a testament to their enduring influence and artistic legacy.

If I were designing a social net, I would make replies only visible by default to the person who posted the message being replying to. There would be an option where the originator could make the reply visible to everyone, if they thought it added something and wasn't just spam, which, these days, so many replies are. The idea of social networks being conversational hasn't been true for a long time. Anyway these days the only tool you have is to block the spammer, which I generally do, esp if the person isn't following me, which imho is a strong indication they were just searching for posts to tag with their spam.

Solving crossword puzzles can be a challenging and rewarding exercise for word enthusiasts. Here are some tips to help you tackle them:

Start with the easy clues: Begin by filling in the words you know for certain. Look for the clues that are straightforward or have a direct connection to your existing answers.

Utilize the crossings: Use intersecting words to your advantage. If you have filled in a few letters in one word, it can help you deduce the letters in the crossing words.

Break down the clue: Analyze the clue's structure and wording. Often, they contain hints such as synonyms, anagrams, or wordplay. Pay attention to tense, plurals, or specific references.

Use a dictionary or online resources: If you're stuck, consult a dictionary or online crossword-solving tools to find potential answers. Remember to use them sparingly to maintain the challenge and satisfaction of solving.

Take breaks and revisit: If you're stuck on a particular clue, take a break and return to it later. Fresh eyes may offer a new perspective and help you find the solution.

Practice regularly: The more puzzles you solve, the better you'll become at deciphering clues and recognizing common crossword patterns and themes.

With patience, persistence, and a bit of wordplay, you'll improve your crossword-solving skills and enjoy the satisfaction of completing these engaging puzzles

Sriracha sauce has earned its reputation as a beloved condiment for numerous reasons, making it undeniably great. One of its standout features is its incredible flavor profile. The combination of sun-ripened chili peppers, garlic, vinegar, sugar, and salt results in a harmonious blend that offers a delightful balance of heat, tanginess, sweetness, and umami. This unique combination adds a layer of complexity to any dish it graces, creating a symphony of flavors on the palate.

Versatility is another key factor contributing to Sriracha's greatness. It seamlessly complements a wide array of cuisines and dishes. Whether you're looking to enhance the flavor of Asian stir-fries, elevate the heat level of a sandwich or burger, or even add a spicy kick to soups and stews, Sriracha is a reliable go-to. It adds depth and excitement to everything from eggs and noodles to pizza and tacos, making it a versatile sauce that can be used in various culinary creations.

Furthermore, Sriracha's iconic packaging with its distinctive rooster logo and vibrant red color has become instantly recognizable worldwide. Its popularity has soared, turning it into a cultural symbol of spiciness and flavor. Its presence on the table often signals an exciting culinary adventure, inviting people to explore new taste sensations and enjoy the thrill of a spicy kick.

In conclusion, Sriracha sauce's exceptional flavor, versatility, and iconic branding have contributed to its widespread acclaim and dedicated following. Its ability to enhance the taste of countless dishes and its unique combination of heat, tang, and sweetness make it an exceptional condiment that continues to captivate taste buds around the globe.

Macaroni and cheese made with a delightful combination of Gouda and Parmesan cheese, combined with old-fashioned elbow macaroni, creates a truly mouthwatering dish. The creamy and slightly smoky notes of Gouda perfectly complement the sharp and nutty flavors of Parmesan, elevating the classic mac and cheese to new levels of deliciousness.

To prepare this delectable dish, start by boiling the elbow macaroni until al dente. While the pasta cooks, grate a generous amount of Gouda and Parmesan cheese. Once the macaroni is cooked, drain it and return it to the pot. Add the grated cheeses and stir until they melt and coat the pasta in a luscious, cheesy blanket.

The result is a velvety, indulgent mac and cheese with a rich, complex flavor profile. The creamy Gouda lends a smooth and creamy texture, while the Parmesan adds a delightful tanginess and depth. The combination of the two cheeses creates a harmonious blend that will tantalize your taste buds and leave you craving more.

Whether enjoyed as a comforting main course or served as a side dish, this Gouda and Parmesan macaroni and cheese is a true crowd-pleaser. The creamy, cheesy goodness combined with the familiar comfort of elbow macaroni is a match made in culinary heaven. One bite of this irresistible creation will transport you to a world of pure satisfaction and leave you with a smile of contentment. Prepare yourself for a delightful and yummy experience that will keep you coming back for seconds and thirds.

Creating a grilled cheese sandwich is a quick and comforting culinary delight. Start by heating a skillet or griddle over medium-low heat. Spread butter on one side of each bread slice. Place one slice, butter-side down, onto the heated surface. Layer slices of cheese on top, and cover with the second bread slice, butter-side up. Cook until the bread turns golden brown and crispy, usually around 2-3 minutes. Carefully flip the sandwich and cook for another 2-3 minutes until the cheese melts and the other side is toasted. Remove from heat, slice, and savor the warm, gooey goodness of a perfect grilled cheese sandwich.

I'm testing the new Thread Writer with some friends.

I was doing a test post to see what happens if my login info is incorrect. I don't think I ever tested that.

Update: There was no error message.

But: I fixed it. :smile:

That's why it's good to get some friends to try things out first, they'll get you thinking about how the software could be work even if you make mistakes.

Making an omelet is a simple yet satisfying culinary endeavor. Begin by cracking a few eggs into a bowl, whisking them until the yolks and whites are fully blended. Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat, adding a knob of butter or a drizzle of oil. Pour the beaten eggs into the pan, allowing them to spread evenly. As the edges begin to set, gently lift and tilt the pan, letting the uncooked egg flow to the edges. Sprinkle your desired fillings, such as cheese, vegetables, or ham, onto one side. Fold the other side over the fillings and cook for a few more moments until the cheese melts. Slide the omelet onto a plate, and voila! A delicious, fluffy omelet awaits, ready to be enjoyed at any time of the day.

I wonder if now what I've been trying to do with RSS, blogging and podcasting, get underneath the bigco's and live on a plane that doesn't require any one of them, makes a bit more sense now.

I'm at least a generation older than most of the other techies who cohabit this space. What you're seeing now for the second or third time,

I've seen five or six times. The more times you see it the more predictable it gets, and the more confidence you have in your understanding.

That's why, when Google tries to take control of the web I won't do it. All my freedom as a developer comes from the integrity of the web. Once its gone you can't get it back.

I could convert completely to HTTPS, it would make my life a bit easier to do so. But I won't as long as Google is forcing it. If they back off and commit to not blocking the non-HTTPS web, then maybe I have more flexibility.

Every company should train an AI chatbot with all current info about everything so people can get answers. Most company info if documented at all is scattered, depends on Google for search, and it increasingly sucks. I spent years not finding a crucial piece of technical info about a company whose products I depend on, till I asked the question on my blog for the Nth time, and most people don’t have the ability to do that. And that's info the company wants people to have, and it ’s well documented on their site. We were supposed to be creating an information rich world, but so far it hasn’t worked. Someone should step up and be the example, reap the competitive benefits.

a certain republican candidate is tapping into our idealized memories of childhood. of course the world is always burning even when we're children, but she's inviting us to return to those "simpler times" when

everything was taken care of for us by parents, and we believed the lies they told us. and even if our childhoods were miserable, we've edited our memories to make them seem idyllic. that's how our memory works.

all around social media people are amplifying her quote, thinking they're outing her, but they're actually helping her, and i'm pretty sure you all know that.

What people love about Bluesky has nothing to do with the software, it's the people. What a lovely group of people. For whatever reason the people who are there now are creative, interested, and stimulated because they sense the presence of similar people. Kind of like Clubhouse was a few summers ago. This tells me something I've suspected, that small-size social networks have a place. They shouldn't just be an accidental thing that disappears because growth attracts less interesting, anti-creative people

I like to write specs for humans.

Imho too many specs are organized the way a computer would need them, the way software is organizing, by establishing basic vocabulary in layers and getting to the conclusions after all that is done.

Humans like it the other way around. Show me how to do X, Y and Z, the most common things want to do with the API, and then later explain how the pieces fit together. The "hello world" approach.

With the arrival of AI, computers can now read what humans read. So you should just write your specs for humans and it'll work fine for computers too!

Gotta change with the times. ;-)

Facebook is launching an ActivityPub service to compete with Mastodon. There's a lot of talk in the webs about locking them out. Big words but not much power behind them.

They will, in an instant, have millions more users than the existing ActivityPub services, so the question really is -- who's being locked out?

It was never a good bet that the architecture of ActivityPub would somehow be able to resist Silicon Valley-scale social networks. That doesn't mean there are no answers, just that bluster isn't one of them. You have to think.

Also it'll be interesting to see how much of ActivityPub Facebook supports in their product. When Google Reader came out for RSS their trick was to break RSS by not supporting a key feature. This did huge damage that we're still dealing with long after Google is gone.

The Bronx High School of Science, founded in 1938, is a prestigious New York City public high school renowned for its rigorous curriculum, particularly in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Admission is based on a competitive exam. The school has consistently ranked among the nation's top high schools and is a member of the National Consortium of Secondary STEM Schools. It boasts a significant number of alumni who have become Nobel Laureates and National Medal of Science recipients. With a diverse student body, Bronx Science, as it's often called, offers a rich educational environment cultivating scientific inquiry and intellectual curiosity.

Arno Schmidt was a German author and translator renowned for his experimental prose and challenging narrative style. Born on January 18, 1914, he experienced World War II as a soldier and prisoner, which deeply impacted his writing. Schmidt's works often grappled with post-war existentialism, employing unique linguistic methods including puns, neologisms, and dense literary references. His magnum opus, "Zettels Traum" ("Bottom's Dream"), is a monumental exploration of language and translation theory. Despite his innovative and complex approach, Schmidt remained a relatively obscure figure in literature during his lifetime. Today, he is regarded as a pioneering postmodern writer.

Mookie Wilson is a former Major League Baseball player best known for his time with the New York Mets from 1980 to 1989. Born on February 9, 1956, in Bamberg, South Carolina, Wilson played as an outfielder and was noted for his exceptional speed and positive attitude. He played a critical role in the Mets' 1986 World Series championship, especially remembered for hitting the ground ball that went through Bill Buckner's legs in Game 6, a pivotal moment in the series. After his playing career, Wilson served as a coach and remains a beloved figure in Mets' history.

Ed Kranepool is a former professional baseball player who spent his entire 18-year Major League Baseball career with the New York Mets. Born on November 8, 1944, in the Bronx, New York, he debuted in the MLB at age 17 in 1962. Primarily a first baseman, Kranepool was known for his solid hitting and fielding. His tenure saw the Mets transform from a new expansion team to 1969 World Series champions, known as the "Miracle Mets." With 1,418 career hits, Kranepool was a fan favorite and a significant part of Mets' history. He retired after the 1979 season.

Batman, also known as Bruce Wayne, is a billionaire industrialist and philanthropist in Gotham City. As a child, Bruce witnessed the murder of his parents, Thomas and Martha Wayne, instilling in him a deep sense of justice. Vowing to avenge their deaths, he trained himself physically and intellectually, donning a bat-themed costume to combat crime. Unlike many superheroes, Batman possesses no superhuman abilities, relying on his intellect, detective skills, technology, wealth, physical prowess, and intimidation. Aided by allies like Robin and Batgirl, and his loyal butler Alfred, Batman battles an array of complex villains, forever committed to safeguarding Gotham.

Superman, birth name Kal-El, was born on the dying planet Krypton before being sent to Earth by his scientist father, Jor-El. Found and adopted by Martha and Jonathan Kent in Smallville, Kansas, he was named Clark Kent. As Clark grew, so did his superhuman abilities, like incredible strength, flight, and invulnerability. Guided by his adoptive parents' morals, he used his powers for good, becoming Superman, the Man of Steel. In his disguise as a mild-mannered reporter for the Daily Planet in Metropolis, he works alongside Lois Lane, his love interest. He consistently fights for truth, justice, and the American way.

Did a thread on this in replies to my own "skeet"

I just can't imagine (at this point) finding an audience without making hustling the newsletter itself a fulltime job. I'd rather just write a few longer pieces and only worry about finding one person willing to pay me for them. It's barely a living, it's true, but it's not a constant hustle.

I've been a blogger. Producing 5 short pieces a day was hard but also I could sometimes post a picture with a single word caption and have it be funny and enough. Would you want to get that as a piece of email? I dunno, maybe I'm justifying my own reluctance to start a newsletter.

As a WRITER, what I want is the mental space to focus on an idea and really think through what I have to say about it. Maybe have someone else look at what I've produce and offer suggestions. Maybe catch errors. Hmmm... What kind of platform would make that possible?

As a reader, I want a collection of the best writing of the week (or day) drawn from a wide variety of people on subjects I care about but als some things I wouldn't have noticed on my own (bc I am busy!)--then put that in one place so I don't have to search for it. Hmmm... What could we call that?

Basically, Substack is a not a journalism model. A few people can make a lot of money, maybe, tho they stand to profit the most if they don't put that many resources into generating content. They might, say, have some tech billionaire spoon feed them a "scoop."

(I am speaking as a writer and consumer not an financial expert but I think this is all relevant) // And then there is the sheer volume of writing! I don't know if there is a single journalist who I want to read 3x a week. I want to dip in and out. Like, uh... a blog.

If I subscribed to all the friends I have who are trying to make a go of it... Well, there are more than 10, so that's $30/mo. The Wash Post, which has writers I love and big investigations and sports (but not necessarily every week) is $40/yr (and free with prime).

How many writers do you think any one person support at $3/month? Then, how many people can command $3/mo? Neither of those numbers are large enough to keep writers there. Then there's "guaranteed income" model for some writers, which is definitely unsustainable.
I just adopted a new kitten so maybe animal-loving socialists are on my mind.
It isn't as important but I also can't get over how doomed the Substack business model is.
